title: 110_s2006
content: The Act may be cited as the "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" and provides disaster assistance for power transmission and distribution facilities. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act defines private or investor-owned power facilities as transmission or distribution facilities providing electric or natural gas service to retail customers. Contributions are subject to conditions outlined in the Act. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act defines private or investor-owned power facilities as transmission or distribution facilities providing electric or natural gas service to retail customers. Assistance is provided for repair, restoration, reconstruction, or replacement of facilities damaged by a major disaster, with conditions outlined in the Act. The President may provide contributions to private or investor-owned power facilities for repair, restoration, or replacement if the costs exceed $2,500 per retail customer affected by the disaster. Total costs for all facilities owned by the person must also be considered. Private or investor-owned power facilities may apply for Federal assistance if their expenses from a previous major disaster exceeded $500,000,000 and if 25% or more of the population in the area had taxable income below the Federal poverty level. Applications must be submitted within 30 days of a major disaster declaration. Private or investor-owned power facilities can receive Federal assistance within 30 days of a major disaster declaration or after contributing $10,000,000 towards repair costs. The assistance is limited to costs exceeding $10,000,000 directly incurred by the owner. The Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act allows for the aggregation of costs from previous major disasters within a 12-month period. The President must approve or disapprove assistance applications within 30 days. Additionally, private or investor-owned power facilities are now eligible for federal assistance under certain conditions. Private or investor-owned power facilities can now receive federal assistance under certain conditions. If the owner determines it's not in the public interest to repair or replace the facility, they can opt for a contribution equal to 75% of the federal estimate cost. This contribution can be used to repair, restore, or expand other power facilities. Private or investor-owned power facilities are now eligible for federal assistance under certain conditions. The amendment allows for funding hazard mitigation measures or constructing new power facilities owned by the person affected by a major disaster. Eligible costs now include private or investor-owned power facilities in addition to public and private nonprofit facilities. The Secretary of Homeland Security must create regulations within 180 days of this Act's enactment to implement the Act and its amendments. The Act and its amendments will take effect 60 days after enactment, with regulations taking effect immediately.
